Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I stood in the breakroom, the smell of hot food filling the air as my coworkers gathered around the table. The foreman had just announced an optional training session for next week, and everyone was excited—free lunch, a chance to learn, and a rare break from the grind. I wanted to be part of the team, to show I was committed and reliable. But as I glanced at the menu posted for the event, my heart sank. None of the catered dishes had kosher certification, and bringing my own food would make me stand out. I could already imagine the questions, the sideways glances. I wanted to fit in, to be seen as just another guy on the crew, but I also felt the weight of my own expectations, the quiet voice reminding me of who I am and what I believe. The laughter and chatter around me faded as I wrestled with the choice—be true to my faith, or blend in with the team.
